response_parsed.title: _pyio Standard Library Module in Python 3.12+: A Comprehensive Guide
response_parsed.summary: This guide delves into the _pyio module, a new addition to Python 3.12+ standard library, which provides an interface for working with binary data streams and offers improved performance over built-in modules.

key_points.description: _pyio was introduced in Python 3.12+ to provide a high-performance alternative for working with binary data streams
_pyio offers efficient IO operations, support for seekable and non-seekable streams, as well as the ability to handle large files more effectively
_pyio addresses some limitations in built-in modules such as itertools.islice and os.fdopen by providing optimized implementations and a unified API
Reading, writing, and seeking binary data using _pyio will be demonstrated with code examples to showcase its ease of use and performance benefits

code_examples.code:
import _pyio

# Reading binary data
with _pyio.open('testfile', 'rb') as f:
    data = f.read()

import _pyio

# Writing binary data
with _pyio.open('newfile', 'wb') as f:
    f.write(b'Hello, World!')

import _pyio

# Seeking in binary data
with _pyio.open('testfile', 'rb') as f:
    f.seek(10)
    byte = f.read(1)

version_notes.note: The _pyio module is available starting from Python 3.12+

caveats.caveat: _pyio should be used for performance-critical applications that involve binary data manipulation. For general file I/O tasks, the built-in modules remain suitable.
_pyio provides an experimental API and may undergo changes in future versions of Python.
